bibl.title: Letter from Albert E. Truby to Philip Showalter Hench, September 26, 1942

div1.p: Truby informs Hench about the progress with his manuscript and credits Hench with having inspired him to write the memoirs.

div1.head: Letter from Albert E. Truby to Philip Showalter Hench, September 26, 1942
div1.opener:
ALBERT E. TRUBY
145 LAUREL STREET
SAN FRANCISCO, CALIFORNIA
Sept. 26/42
Dear Colonel Hench:
div1.p:
It is nice to greet you
with a military title, nice to welcome
you into the service. You will soon
adjust yourself to service conditions
and find yourself ready for anything
that comes your way. Thanks for
the photo. Things seem awfully bare and
lifeless around the new buildings, but
when car loads of patients begin to
arrive there will be plenty of work and
things will liven up. As Chief of the
Medical Service you will find plenty of
interesting work to do and later on
you can delegate most of the clerical
work to your assistants. I think I have
met Col. Hunter, but I don't think that
we have ever served together.

There is nothing new here. The S.G.O.
still has my mms. and I have had
no definite info. as to what will
be done. Col. Rogers (Executive Officer)
AC
T
wrote me recently and said he
was having it gone over by Gens. Love,
Hillman, Col. Simmons and others. As
they are all busy men I am letting
them take their time and not pestering
them with inquiries from here. In
due time I feel sure that they will
come across with a favorable action.

I was most pleased with the Introduction
which General Kean wrote. I will see
that your middle letter S. is replaces
the L. when I receive the mms. back
for final additions & corrections. Kean
did not over-emphasize your efforts
and the enthusiasm you instilled in us.
I doubt if I ever would have finished
the crude draft I first sent you if you
had not impressed me with your keen
interest. It was then that I really
felt that I must get it in shape
for publication. The many questionaires
you sent me made me look up the
answers if possible, and thus brought
out many dormant memories. I feel
greatly indebted to General K. for bringing
out your great help to me.

As soon as I hear anything from Washington
I will let you know. Am glad you found
the Y.F. charts which Ames had. I never knew
Mrs. Ames. Do you know when he married her? after 1900 I think)
with the best of luck and much happiness for
you in your new work.
